repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Pension and Financial Market
            Reform Technical Assistance Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
The Pension and Financial Market Reform
            Technical Assistance Credit for Nicaragua had the following
            ratings: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: When
            political risks are high, project design should be much less
            ambitious with respect to policy reform commitments. Short
            and medium-run costs of reforms may be unacceptable despite
            potential long-term benefits. Lack of Borrower ownership
            will delay project implementation and undermine outcomes.
            Project design should not be too ambitious but based on
            capacity on the ground. Project appraisal should include an
            in depth analysis of financial and political risks. Public
            information campaigns should follow, not precede, the
            implementation of a reform and should focus on the reasons
            for the reforms, and present realistic expectations of their
            benefits. Having the right project coordination agency will
            result in a better implementation experience.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Pension and Financial Market
            Reform Technical Assistance Credit Project : proposed
            amendment to the credit agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
This report comprises a proposed
            Amendment to the Nicaragua Pension and Financial Market
            Reform Technical Assistance Credit Agreement (Credit
            3344-NI). This Amendment is being made to reflect
            significant factors that affected the course of project
            implementation and will have an impact on the overall
            project outcome. These factors include (i) a substantial
            level of systemic instability, culminating in the
            generalized banking crisis in late 2000; (ii) a change of
            administration in Nicaragua in January 2002, bringing about
            a restructuring and related personnel changes at the
            project's counterpart agency; and (iii) higher actual
            costs for selected activities versus the original budget,
            with specific project activities under the first two
            components being much more costly than anticipated. Amending
            the Credit Agreement will bring the development objectives
            more in line with the current realities of the project, and
            extend the project closing date to December 3 1,2004.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Pension and Financial Market
            Reform Technical Assistance Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Pension and
            Financial Market Reform Technical Assistance Project, is to
            support the Government's plan to create an equitable,
            and sustainable system of old-age income security. The
            components will: 1) implement the parametric reform of the
            Pay-as-you-go (PAYG) system, through verification of the
            Instituto Nicaraguense de Seguro Social (INSS) database, the
            establishment of consensus on projections, and through
            costs' stimulation of reform options. The method for
            recognizing acquired rights will be determined, and the
            capacity of the INSS will be strengthened to develop
            pension-related information systems, and administration. The
            component will also include the design of legal, regulatory,
            and institutional framework for a defined contribution of
            the pension system, and that of targeted public pillars to
            determine alternative financing, for the conversion of the
            PAYG to a Defined Contribution (DC) system. A Public
            awareness campaign will be developed; 2) design, and develop
            the organizational structure, institutional by-laws, and
            operating manuals, and procedures towards a personnel
            training plan; and, 3) identify, and introduce new
            insurance, and capital markets instruments for a pension
            fund investment, by implementing a revision framework for
            private sector participation in new pension aspects. Banking
            and financial institutions will be strengthened within a
            legal framework.
